nodes.text: Conservation of money within agent transactions, combined with methods of statistical physics, explains stationary money and income distributions and sheds light on inequality, debt dynamics, and the role of the state in modern monetary economies
Money in ordinary peer-to-peer transactions obeys a local conservation law: transfers change individual balances but leave the sum of the participants accounts unchanged
Under microscopic time-reversal symmetry (detailed balance) and conservation, the stationary distribution of a conserved scalar (money) is exponential (Boltzmann-Gibbs)

Boltzmann kinetic equation for money transfers and its reduction to the Fokker-Planck (Kolmogorov forward) equation provide a methodology to derive stationary distributions and relate drift/diffusion coefficients to money temperature

If transfer rules are additive and/or satisfy time-reversal symmetry the stationary solution is exponential; multiplicative or mixed transfer rules produce Gamma-like or power-law tails (non-exponential)

Entropy maximization (Boltzmann principle) with fixed total money explains the emergence of the exponential distribution as the maximal-entropy equilibrium and implies spontaneous growth of inequality from equal initial conditions
Empirical income data (US Census and IRS) show a two-class structure: a majority lower class well described by an exponential distribution and an upper class following a Pareto power law

Money and physical goods form two distinct coupled layers: a monetary informational layer (conserved digital tokens) and a physical production layer (nonconserved goods); conflating them causes conceptual errors
The state (central bank) can exogenously inject money across the system boundary via vertical transactions (issuing fiat, buying bonds), changing total money M and affecting money per capita Tm

Kinetic models that treat wealth conservatively (wealth transfer rules) are conceptually misleading because wealth includes prices and physical volumes which change between transactions; such models should focus on money transfers instead

Commercial banks create matched loan-deposit pairs (debt and corresponding deposit liabilities), which increases money-in-circulation among agents but is functionally creation of debt not exogenous money; reserves remain conserved in interbank clearing

Unrestricted debt creation removes the lower-bound boundary condition on net worth and leads to indefinite broadening of the net-worth distribution (growing entropy), destabilizing the system unless debt constraints or interventions occur

When widespread debt collapses, central bank monetization (bailouts, QE) replaces private endogenous debt with exogenous state money, which preferentially benefits financial actors and increases income inequality (empirical spikes coincide with market bubbles and QE)

The ultimate source of aggregate capitalist monetary profit (net increase of money balances for the capitalist class) in practice is state-created exogenous money injected during bailouts and monetization events

Quantitative Easing and other central-bank asset purchases channel new money to banks and financial markets, amplifying upper-tail income share (supported by IRS data showing inequality spikes during QE and market bubbles)

Limitations and assumptions include: idealized agent-based models may omit production dynamics and network topology changes, distinction between money and wealth may be blurred in many studies, and globalized capital flows complicate national monetary effects
